She has no conventional gestures, and none of any sort at first. As she warms to her work she uses her slim hands to enforce her emphasis, but as though unconsciously. Her manner of speech is less monotonous than that of the average woman‐speaker, but she, too, has a fashion of leaning all her weight on the end of the sentence. She brings out the final word or two with an effort of underscoring, and makes a forward motion of the slim body as if the better to drive the last nail in.
She evidently means to be immensely practical—the kind who is pleased to think she hasn’t a grain of sentimentality in her composition, and whose feeling, when it does all but master her, communicates itself magnetically to others.)

sp.speaker: MISS ERNESTINE BLUNT.
sp.p: Perhaps I’d better begin by explaining a little about our “tactics.” (Cries of “Tactics! We know!” “Mykin’ trouble!” “Public scandal!”) To make you understand what we’ve done, I must remind you of what others have done. Perhaps you don’t know that women first petitioned Parliament for the Franchise as long ago as 1866.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: How do you know?

div.stage: (She pauses a moment, taken off her guard by the suddenness of the attack.)

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: You wasn’t there!

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: That was the trouble. Haw! haw!

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: And the petition was presented—

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Give ’er a ’earin’ now she ’as got out of ’er crydle.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p:
—presented to the House of Commons by that great Liberal, John Stuart Mill. (Voices: “Mill? Who is he when he’s at home?”) Bills or Resolutions have been before the House on and off for the last thirty‐six years. That, roughly, is our history. We found ourselves, towards the close of the year 1905, with no assurance that if we went on in the same way any girl born into the world in this generation would live to exercise the rights of citizenship, though she lived to be a hundred. So we said all this has been in
vain. We must try some other way. How did the working man get the Suffrage, we asked ourselves? Well, we turned up the records, and we saw—

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: “Not by scratching people’s faces!” . . . “Disraeli give it ’em” “Dizzy? Get out!” “Cahnty Cahncil scholarships!” “Oh, Lord, this education!” “Chartist riots, she’s thinkin’ of!” (Noise in the crowd.)

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: But we don’t want to follow such a violent example. We would much rather not—but if that’s the only way we can make the country see we’re in earnest, we are prepared to show them.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: An’ they’ll show you!—Give you another month ’ard.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Don’t think that going to prison has any fears for us. We’d go for life if by doing that we could get freedom for the rest of the women.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: “Hear, hear!” “Rot!” “W’y don’t the men ’elp ye to get your rights?”

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Here’s some one asking why the men don’t help. It’s partly they don’t understand yet—they will before we’ve done! (Laughter.) Partly they don’t understand yet what’s at stake—

sp.speaker: RESPECTABLE OLD MAN
sp.p: Lord, they’re a ’educatin’ of us!

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Wot next?

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p:
—and partly that the bravest man is afraid of ridicule. Oh, yes; we’ve heard a great deal all our lives about the timidity and the sensitiveness of women. And it’s true. We are sensitive. But I tell you, ridicule crumples a man up. It steels a woman. We’ve come to know the value of ridicule. We’ve educated ourselves so that we welcome ridicule. We owe our sincerest thanks to the comic writers.
The cartoonist is our unconscious friend. Who cartoons people who are of no importance? What advertisement is so sure of being remembered?

sp.speaker: POETIC YOUNG MAN.
sp.p: I admit that.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: If we didn’t know it by any other sign, the comic papers would tell us we’ve arrived! But our greatest debt of gratitude we owe, to the man who called us female hooligans. (The crowd bursts into laughter.) We aren’t hooligans, but we hope the fact will be overlooked. If everybody said we were nice, well‐behaved women, who’d come to hear us? Not the men. (Roars.) Men tell us it isn’t womanly for us to care about politics. How do they know what’s womanly? It’s for women to decide that. Let the men attend to being manly. It will take them all their time.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Are we down‐’earted? Oh no!

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: And they say it would be dreadful if we got the vote, because then we’d be pitted against men in the economic struggle. But that’s come about already. Do you know that out of every hundred women in this country eighty‐two are wage‐earning women? It used to be thought unfeminine for women to be students and to aspire to the arts—that bring fame and fortune. But nobody has ever said it was unfeminine for women to do the heavy drudgery that’s badly paid. That kind of work had to be done by somebody—and the men didn’t hanker after it. Oh, no.

div.stage: (Laughter and interruption.)

sp.speaker: A MAN ON THE OUTER FRINGE.
sp.p: She can talk—the little one can.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER.
sp.p: Oh, they can all “talk.”

sp.speaker: A BEERY, DIRTY FELLOW OF FIFTY.
sp.p: I wouldn’t like to be ’er ’usban’. Think o’ comin’ ’ome to that!

sp.speaker: HIS PAL.
sp.p: I’d soon learn ’er!

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Oh, no! Let the women scrub and cook and wash. That’s all right! But if they want to try their hand at the better paid work of the liberal professions—oh, very unfeminine indeed! Then there’s another thing. Now I want you to listen to this, because it’s very> important. Men say if we persist in competing with them for the bigger prizes, they’re dreadfully afraid we’d lose the beautiful protesting chivalry that—Yes, I don’t wonder you laugh. We laugh. (Bending forward with lit eyes.) But the women I found at the Ferry Tin Works working for five shillings a week—I didn’t see them laughing. The beautiful chivalry of the employers of women doesn’t prevent them from paying women tenpence a day for sorting coal and loading and unloading carts—doesn’t prevent them from forcing women to earn bread in ways worse still. So we won’t talk about chivalry. It’s being over‐;sarcastic. We’ll just let this poor ghost of chivalry go—in exchange for a little plain justice.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: If the House of Commons won’t give you justice, why don’t you go to the House of Lords?

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Better ’urry up. Case of early closin’.

div.stage: (Laughter. A man at the back asks the speaker something.)

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: You’ll be allowed to ask any question you like at the end of the meeting.

sp.speaker: NEW‐COMER
sp.p: Oh, is it question time? I s’y, Miss, ’oo killed cock robin?

div.stage: (She is about to resume, but above the general noise the voice of a man at the back reaches her indistinct but insistent. She leans forwards trying to catch what he says. While the indistinguishable murmur has been going on GEOFFREY STONOR has appeared on the edge of the crowd, followed by JEAN and LADY JOHN in motor veils.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Is she one of them? That little thing!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I—I suppose so.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Oh, ask some one, Geoffrey. I’m so disappointed. I did so hope we’d hear one of the—the worst.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: What? What do you say? (She screws up her eyes with the effort to hear, and puts a hand up to her ear. A few indistinguishable words between her and the man.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.stage: (who has been studying the figures on the platform through her lorgnon, turns to a working man beside her).
sp.p: Can you tell me, my man, which are the ones that—a—that make the disturbances?

sp.speaker: WORKING MAN.
sp.p: The one that’s doing the talking—she’s the disturbingest o’ the lot.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Not that nice little—

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Oh, yes—I see. There’s a man over here asking—

sp.speaker: A YOUNG MAN.
sp.p: I’ve got a question too. Are—you—married?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: Quick! There’s yer chawnce. ’E’s a bachelor.

div.stage: (Laughter).

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.stage: (goes straight on as if she had not heard)
sp.p: —man asking: if the women get full citizenship, and a war is declared, will the women fight?

sp.speaker: POETIC YOUNG MAN.
sp.p: No, really—no, really, now!

div.stage: (The Crowd: “Haw! Haw!” “Yes!” “Yes, how about that?”)

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Well, you know, some people say the whole trouble about us is that we do fight. But it is only hard necessity makes us do that. We don’t want to fight—as men seem to—just for fighting’s sake. Women are for peace.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Hear, hear.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: And when we have a share in public affairs there’ll be less likelihood of war. But that’s not to say women can’t fight. The Boer women did. The Russian women face conflicts worse than any battlefield can show. (Her voice shakes a little, and the eyes fill, but she controls her emotion gallantly, and dashes on.) But we women know all that is evil, and we’re for peace. Our part—we’re proud to remember it—our part has been to go about after you men in war‐time, and pick up the pieces! (A great shout.) Yes—seems a bit funny, doesn’t it? You men blow them to bits, and then we come along and put them together again. If you know anything about military nursing, you know a good deal of our work has been done in the face of danger—but it’s always been done.

sp.speaker: OLD NEWSVENDOR
sp.p: That’os so. That’s so.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: You complain that more and more we’re taking away from you men the work that’s always been yours. You can’t any longer keep women out of the industries. The only question is upon what terms shall she continue to be in? As long as she’s in on bad terms, she’s not only hurting herself—she’s hurting you. But if you’re feeling discouraged about our competing with you, we’re willing to leave you your trade in war. Let the men take life! We give life! (Her voice is once more moved and proud.) No one will pretend ours isn’t one of the dangerous trades either. I won’t say any more to you now, because we’e got others to speak to you, and a new woman‐helper that I want you to hear.

div.stage: (She retires to the sound of clapping. There’s a hurried consultation between her and the CHAIRMAN. Voices in the Crowd: “The little ’un’s all right” “Ernestine’s a corker,” &c.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (looking at STONOR to see how he’s taken it).
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Nothing reprehensible in what she said, was there?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Oh, reprehensible!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: It makes me rather miserable all the same.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (draws her hand protectingly through his arm).
sp.p: You mustn’t take it as much to heart as all that.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: I can’t help it—I can’t indeed, Geoffrey. I shall never be able to make a speech like that!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I hope not, indeed.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Why, I thought you said you wanted me—?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: To make nice little speeches with composure—so I did! So I— (Seems to lose his thread as he looks at her.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You said—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: That you have very pink cheeks? Well, I stick to that.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Sh! Don’t tell everybody.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: And you’re the only female creature I ever saw who didn’t look a fright in motor things.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I’m glad you don’t think me a fright.

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN.
sp.p: I will now ask (name indistinguishable) to address the meeting.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (as she sees LADY JOHN moving to one side).
sp.p: Oh, don’t go yet, Aunt Ellen!

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Go? Certainly not. I want to hear another. (Craning her neck.) I can’t believe, you know, she was really one of the worst.

div.stage: (A big, sallow Cockney has come forward. His scanty hair grows in wisps on a great bony skull.)

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: That’s Pilcher.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER.
sp.p: ’Oo’s Pilcher?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER.
sp.p: If you can’t afford a bottle of Tatcho, w’y don’t you get yer ’air cut.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p:
I’ve been addressin’ a big meetin’ at ’Ammersmith this morning, and w’en I told ’em I wus comin’ ’ere this awfternoon to speak fur the women—well—then the usual thing began! (An appreciative roar from the crowd.)
In these times if you want peace and quiet at a public meetin’ (The crowd fills in the hiatus with laughter.) There was a man at ’Ammersmith, too, talkin’ about women’s sphere bein’ ’ome. ’Ome do you call it? You’ve got a kennel w’ere you can munch your tommy. You’ve got a corner w’ere you can curl up fur a few hours till you go out to work again. No, my man, there’s too many of you ain’t able to give the women ’omes—fit to live in, too many of you in that fix fur you to go on jawin’ at those o’ the women ’oo want to myke the ’omes a little decenter.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: If the vote ain’t done us any good, ’ow’ll it do the women any good?

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: Look ’ere! Any men here belongin’ to the Labour Party? (Shouts and applause.) Well, I don’t need to tell these men the vote ’as done us some good. They know it. And it’ll do us a lot more food w’en you know ’ow to use the power you got in you ’and.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Power! It’s those fellers at the bottom o’ the street that’s got the power.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: It’s you, and men like you, that gave it to ’em. You carried the Liberals into Parliament Street on your own shoulders. (complacent applause.) You believed all their fine words. You never asked yourselves, “Wot’s a Liberal, anyw’y?”

sp.speaker: A VOICE.
sp.p: He’s a jolly good fellow.

div.stage: (Cheers and booing.)

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: No, ’e ain’t, or of ’e is jolly, it’s only because ’e thinks you’re such a silly codfish you’ll go swellin’ his majority again. (Laughter, in which STONOR joins.) It’s enough to make any Liberal jolly to see sheep like you lookin’ on, proud and ’appy, while you see Liberal leaders desertin’ Liberal principles. (Voices in agreement and protest.) You show me a Liberal, and I’ll show you a Mr. Fycing‐both‐W’ys. Yuss. (STONOR moves closer with an amused look.) ’E sheds the light of ’is warm and ’andsome smile on the working man, and round on the other side ’e’s tippin’ a wink to the great land‐owners. That’s to let ’em know ’e’s standin’ between them and the Socialists. Yuss, Socialists! (General laughter, in which STONOR joins.) The Liberal, e’s the judicial sort o’ chap that sits in the middle—

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: On the fence!

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: Tories one side—Socialists the other. Well it ain’t always so comfortable in the middle. You’re like to get squeezed. Now, I s’y to the women, the Conservatives don’t promise you much but what they promise they do!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: This fellow isn’t half bad.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: The Liberals—they’ll promise you the earth, and give yer . . . the whole o’ nothing.

div.stage: (Roars of approval.)

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Isn’t it fun? Now, aren’t you glad I brought you?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: This chap’s rather amusing!

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: We men ’ave seen it ’appen over and over. But the women can tyke a ’int quicker’n what we can. They won’t stand the nonsense men do. Only they ’aven’t got a fair chawnce even to agitate fur their rights. As I wus comin’ up ’ere I ’eard a man sayin’, “Look at this big crowd. W’y, we’re all men! If the women want the vote w’y ain’t they ’ere to s’y so?” Well, I’ll tell you w’y. It’s because they’ve ’ad to get the dinner fur you and me, and now they’re washin’ up the dishes.

sp.speaker: A VOICE.
sp.p: D’you think we ought to st’y ’ome and wash the dishes?

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: If they’d leave it to us once or twice per’aps we’d understand a little more about the Woman Question. I know w’y my wife isn’t here. It’s because she knows I ain’t much use round the ’ouse, and she’s ’opin’ I can talk to some purpose. Maybe she’s mistaken. Any’ow, here I am to vote for her and all the other women. (“Hear! hear!” “Oh‐h!”) And to tell you men what improvements you can expect to see when women ’as the share in public affairs they ought to ’ave!

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: What do you know about it? You can’t even talk grammar.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.stage: (is dashed a fraction of a moment, for the first and only time).
sp.p: I’m not ’ere to talk grammar but to talk Reform. I ain’t defendin’ my grammar—but I’ll say in pawssing that if my mother ’ad ’ad ’er rights, maybe my grammar would have been better.

div.stage:
(STONOR and JEAN exchange smiles. He takes her arm again and bends his head to whisper something in her ear. She listens
with lowered eyes and happy faces. The discreet love‐making goes on during the next few sentences. Interruption. One voice insistent but not clear. The speaker waits only a second and then resumes. “Yes, if the women,” but he cannot instantly make himself heard. The boyish CHAIRMAN looks harassed and anxious. MISS ERNESTINE BLUNT alert, watchful.)

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: Wait a bit—’arf a minute, my man!

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: ’Oo yer talkin’ to? I ain’t your man.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: Lucky for me! There seems to be a gentleman ’ere who doesn’t think women ought to ’ave the vote.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: One? Oh‐'h!

div.stage: (Laughter.)

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p:
Per’aps ’e doesn’t know much about women? (Indistinguishable repartee.) Oh, the gentleman says ’e’s married. Well, then, fur the syke of ’is wife we musn’t be too sorry ’e’s ’ere. No doubt she’s s’ying: “’Eaven by prysed those women are mykin’ a Demonstrytion in Trafalgar Square, and I’ll ’ave a little peace and quiet at ’ome for one Sunday in my life.” (The crowd laughs and there are jeers for the interrupter—and at the speaker.)(Pointing.) Why, you’re like the man at ’Ammersmith this morning. ’E was awskin’ me: “’Ow would you like men to st’y at ’ome and do the fam’ly washin’?” (Laughter.)
I told ’im I wouldn’t advise it. I ’ave too much respect fur—me clo’es.

sp.speaker: VAGRANT.
sp.p: It’s their place—the women ought to do the washin’.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: I’m not sure you ain’t right. For a good many o’ you fellas, from the look o’ you—you cawn’t even wash yerselves.

div.stage: (Laughter.)

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: ’Oo are you talkin’ to?

div.stage: (Chairman more anxious than before—movement in the crowd.)

sp.speaker: THREATENING VOICE.
sp.p: Which of us d’you mean?

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.p: Well, it takes about ten of your sort to myke a man, so you may take it I mean the lot of you.

div.stage: (Angry indistinguishable retorts and the crowd sways. MISS ERNESTINE BLUNT, who has been watching the fray with serious face, turns suddenly, catching sight of some one just arrived at the end of the platform. MISS BLUNT goes R. with alacrity, saying audibly to PILCHER as she passes, “Here she is,” and proceeds to offer her hand helping some one to get up the improvised steps. Laughter and interruption in the crowd.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Now, there’s another woman going to speak.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Oh, is she? Who? Which? I do hope she’ll be one of the wild ones.

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.stage:
(speaking through this last. Glancing at the new arrival whose hat appears above the platform
R.).
sp.p: That’s all right, then. (Turns to the left.) When I’ve attended to this microbe that’s vitiating the air on my right—

div.stage: (Laughter and interruptions from the crowd.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (staring R., one dazed instant, at the face of the new arrival, his own changes).
(JEAN withdraws her arm from his and quite suddenly presses a shade nearer the platform. STONOR moves forward and takes her by the arm.)
sp.p: We’re going now.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Not yet—oh, please not yet. (Breathless, looking back.) Why I—I do believe—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I’m going to take JEAN out of this mob. Will you come?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: What? Oh yes, if you think— (Another look through her glasses.) But isn’t that—surely its—! ! !

div.stage: (VIDA LEVERING comes forward R. She wears a long, plain, dark green dust‐cloak. Stands talking to ERNESTINE BLUNT and glancing a little apprehensively at the crowd.)

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Geoffrey!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Lady John’s tired—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: But you don’t see who it is, Geoffrey—! (Looks into his face, and is arrested by the look she finds there.)

div.stage:
LADY JOHN has pushed in front of them amazed, transfixed, with
                    glass up. GEOFFREY STONOR restrains a gesture of annoy‐
 ance, and withdraws behind two big policemen. JEAN
                    from time to time turns to look at him with a face of perplexity.)

sp.speaker: MR. P.
sp.stage: (resuming through a fire of indistinct interruption).
sp.p: I’ll come down and attend to that microbe while a lady will say a few words to you (raises his voice)—if she can myke ’herself ’eard.

div.stage: (PILCHER retires in the midst of booing and cheers.)

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN
sp.stage: (harassed and trying to create a diversion).
sp.p: Some one suggests—and it’s such a good idea I’d like you to listen to it— (Noise dies down.) that a clause shall be inserted in the next Suffrage Bill that shall expressly reserve to each Cabinet Minister, and to any respectable man, the power to prevent the Franchise being given to the female members of his family on his public declaration of their lack of sufficient intelligence to entitle them to vote.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN.
sp.p: Now, I ask you to listen, as quietly as you can, to a lady who is not accustomed to speaking—a—in Trafalgar Square—or a . . . as a matter of fact, at all.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: “A dumb lady.” “Hooray!” “Three cheers for the dumb lady!”

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN.
sp.p: A lady who, as I’ve said, will tell you, if you’ll behave yourselves, her impressions of the administration of police‐court justice in this country.

div.stage: (JEAN looks wondering at STONOR’S sphinx‐like face as VIDA LEVERING comes to the edge of the platform.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Mr. Chairman, men and women—

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Speak up.

div.stage: (She flushes, comes quite to the edge of the platform and raises her voice a little.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I just wanted to tell you that I was—I was—present in the police‐court when the women were charged for creating a disturbance.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Y’oughtn’t t’ get mixed up in wot didn’t concern you.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I—I— (Stumbles and stops.)

div.stage: (Talking and laughing increases. “Wot’s ’er name?” “Mrs. or Miss?” “Ain’t seen this one before.”)

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN
sp.p: Now, see here, men; don’t interrupt—

sp.speaker: A GIRL
sp.p: I like this on’s ’at. Ye can see she ain’t one of ’em.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I—

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: They’re a disgrace—them women be’ind yer.

sp.speaker: A MAN WITH A FATHERLY AIR.
sp.p: It’s the w’y goes on as mykes the Government keep ye from gettin’ yer rights.

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN
sp.p: It’s the way you go on that—

div.stage: (Noise increases. CHAIRMAN drowned, waves his arms and moves his lips. MISS LEVERING discouraged, turns and looks at ERNESTINE BLUNT and pantomimes “It’s no good. I can’t go on.” ERNESTINE BLUNT comes forward, says a word to the CHAIRMAN, who ceases gyrating, and nods.)

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: Look here. If the Government withhold the vote because they don’t like the way some of us ask for it—let them give it to the Quiet Ones. Does the Government want to punish all women because they don’t like the manners of a handful? Perhaps that’s you men’s notion of justice. It isn’t women’s.

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Haw! haw!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Yes, Th‐this is the first time I’ve ever “gone on,” as you call it, but they never gave me a vote.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: No! And there are one—two—three—four women on this platform. Now, we all want the vote, as you know. Well, we’d agree to be disfranchised all our lives, if they’d give the vote to all the other women.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Look here, you made one speech, give the lady a chawnce.

sp.speaker: MISS E.B.
sp.p: That’s just what I wanted you to do!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Perhaps you—you don’t know—you don’t know—

sp.speaker: VOICE
sp.p: ’Ow ’re we goin’ to know if you can’t tell us?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Thank you for that. We couldn’t have a better motto. How are you to know if we can’t somehow manage to tell you? (With a visible effort she goes on.) Well, I certainly didn’t know before that the sergeants and policemen are instructed to deceive the people as to the time such cases are heard. You ask, and you’re sent to Marlborough Police Court instead of to Marylebone.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: They ought ter sent yer to ’Olloway—do y’ good.

sp.speaker: OLD NEWSVENDOR.
sp.p: You go on, Miss, don’t mind ’im.

sp.speaker: VOICE.
sp.p: Wot d’you expect from a pig but a grunt?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You’re told the case will be at two o’clock, and it’s really called for eleven. Well, I took a great deal of trouble, and I didn’t believe what I was told— (Warming a little to her task.) Yes, that’s almost the first thing we have to learn—to get over our touching faith that, because a man tells us something, it’s true. I got to the right court, and I was so anxious not to be late, I was too early. The case before the Women’s was just coming on. I heard a noise. At the door I saw the helmets of two policemen, and I said to myself: “What sort of crime shall I have to sit and hear about? Is this a burglar coming along between the two big policemen, or will it be a murderer? What sort of felon is to stand in the dock before the women whose crime is they ask for the vote?” But, try as I would, I couldn’t see the prisoner. My heart misgave me. Is it a woman, I wondered? Then the policemen got nearer, and I saw—(she waits an instant)—a little, thin, half‐starved boy. What do you think he was charged with? Stealing. What had he been stealing—that small criminal? Milk. It seemed to me as I sat there looking on, that the men who had the affairs of the world in their hands from the beginning, and who’ve made so poor a business of it—

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Oh! oh! Pore benighted man! Are we down‐’earted? Oh, no!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
—so poor a business of it as to have the poor and the unemployed in the condition they’re in to‐day—when your only remedy for a starving child
is to hale him off to the police‐court—because he had managed to get a little milk—well, I did wonder that the men refuse to be helped with a problem they’ve so notoriously failed at. I began to say to myself: “Isn’t it time the women lent a hand?”

sp.speaker: A VOICE.
sp.p: Would you have women magistrates?

div.stage: (She is stumped by the suddenness of the demand.)

sp.speaker: VOICES.
sp.p: Haw! Haw! Magistrates!

sp.speaker: ANOTHER.
sp.p: Women! Let ’em prove first they deserve—

sp.speaker: A SHABBY ART STUDENT
sp.stage: (his hair longish, soft hat, and flowing tie).
sp.p: They study music by thousands; where’s their Beethoven? Where’s their Plato? Where’s the woman Shakespeare?

sp.speaker: ANOTHER.
sp.p: Yes—what’a’ they ever done?

div.stage: (The speaker clenches her hands, and is recovering her presence of mind, so that by the time the CHAIRMAN can make himself heard with, “Now, men, give this lady a fair hearing—don’t interrupt”—she, with the slightest of gestures, waves him aside with a low “It’s all right.”)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: These questions are quite proper! They are often asked elsewhere; and I would like to ask in return: Since when was human society held to exist for its handful of geniuses? How many Platos are there here in this crowd?

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Divil a wan!

div.stage: (Laughter.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
Not one. Yet that doesn’t keep you men off the register. How many Shakespeares are
there in all England to‐day? Not one. Yet the State doesn’t tumble to pieces. Railroads and ships are built—homes are kept going, and babies are born. The world goes on! (bending over the crowd) It goes on by virtue of its common people.

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Hear! hear!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I am not concerned that you should think we women can paint great pictures, or compose immortal music, or write good books. I am content that we should be classed with the common people—who keep the world going. But (staightening up and taking a fresh start), I’d like the world to go a great deal better. We were talking about justice. I have been inquiring into the kind of lodging the poorest class of homeless women can get in this town of London. I find that only the men of that class are provided for. Some measure to establish Rowton Houses for women has been before the London County Council. They looked into the question “very carefully,” so their apologists say. And what did they decide? They decided that they could do nothing.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.stage: (having forced her way to STONOR’S side).
sp.p: Is that true?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I don’t know.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Why could that great, all‐powerful body do nothing? Because, if these cheap and decent houses were opened, they said, the homeless women in the streets would make use of them! You’ll think I’m not in earnest. But that was actually the decision and the reason given for it. Women that the bitter struggle for existence has forced into a life of horror—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You think this is the kind of thing— (A motion of the head towards JEAN.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: —the outcast women might take advantage of the shelter these decent, cheap places offered. But the men, I said! Are all who avail themselves of the Lord Rowton’s hostels, are they all angels? Or does wrong‐doing in a man not matter? Yet women are recommended to depend on the chivalry of men.

div.stage: (The two policemen, who at first had been strolling about, have stood during this scene in front of GEOFFREY STONOR. They turn now and walk away, leaving STONOR exposed. He, embarrassed, moves uneasily, and VIDA LEVERING’S eye falls upon his big figure. He still has the collar of his motor coat turned up to his ears. A change passes over her face, and her nerve fails her an instant.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
Justice and chivalry! ! (she steadies her voice and hurries on)—they both remind me of what those of you who read the police‐court news—(I have begun only lately to do that)—but you’ve seen the accounts of the girl who’s been tried in Manchester lately for the murder of her child. Not pleasant reading. Even if we’d noticed it, we wouldn’t speak of it in my world. A few months ago I should have turned away my eyes and forgotten even the headline as quickly as I could. But since that morning in the police‐court, I read these things. This, as you’ll remember, was about a little working girl—an orphan of eighteen—who crawled with the dead
body of her new‐born child to her master’s back‐door, and left the baby there. She dragged herself a little way off and fainted. A few days later she found herself in court, being tried for the murder of her child. Her master—a married man—had of course reported the “find” at his back‐door to the police, and he had been summoned to give evidence. The girl cried out to him in the open court, “You are the father!” He couldn’t deny it. The Coroner at the jury’s request censured the man, and regretted that the law didn’t make him responsible. But he went scot‐free. And that girl is now serving her sentence in Strangeways Gaol.

div.stage: (Murmuring and scraps of indistinguishable comment in the crowd, through which only JEAN’S voice is clear.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (who has wormed her way to STONOR’S side).
sp.p: Why do you dislike her so?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I? Why should you think—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: I never saw you look as you did—as you do.

sp.speaker: CHAIRMAN.
sp.p: Order, please—give the lady a fair—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
Men make boast that an English citizen is tried by his peers. What woman is tried by hers? (A sombre passion strengthens her voice and hurries her on.) A woman is arrested by a man, brought before a man judge, tried by a jury of men, condemned by men, taken to prison by a man, and by a man she’s hanged! Where in all this were her “peers”? Why did men so long ago insist on trial by “a jury of their peers”? So that justice shouldn’t miscarry—wasn’t it? A
man’s peers would best understand his circumstances, his temptation, the degree of his guilt. Yet there’s no such unlikeness between different classes of men as exists between man and woman. What man has the knowledge that makes him a fit judge of a woman’s deeds at that time of anguish—that hour— (lowers her voice and bends over the crowd) —that hour that some woman struggled through to put each man here into the world. I noticed when a previous speaker quoted the Labour Party you applauded. Some of you here—I gather—call yourselves Labour men. Every woman who has borne a child is a Labour woman. No man among you can judge what she goes through in her hour of darkness—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (with frightened eyes on her lover’s set, white face, whispers).
sp.p: Geoffrey—

sp.speaker: MISS L
sp.stage: (catching her fluttering breath, goes on very low)
sp.p:
—in that great agony when, even under the best conditions that money and devotion can buy, many a woman falls into temporary mania, and not a few go down to death. In the case of this poor little abandoned working girl, what man can be the fit judge of her deeds in that awful moment of half‐crazed temptation? Women know of these things as those know burning who have walked through fire. (STONOR makes a motion towards JEAN and she turns away fronting the audience. Her hands go to her throat as though she suffered a choking sensation. It is in her face that she “knows.” MISS LEVERING leans over the platform and speaks with a low and thrilling earnestness.) I would say in conclusion to the women here, it’s not
enough to be sorry for these our unfortunate sisters. We must get the conditions of life made fairer. We women must organise. We must learn to work together. We have all (rich and poor, happy and unhappy) worked so long and so exclusively for men, we hardly know how to work for one another. But we must learn. Those who can, may give money—

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Oh, yes—Money! Money!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Those who haven’t pennies to give—even those people aren’t so poor they can’t give some part of their labour—some share of their sympathy and support.

div.stage: (Turns to hear something the CHAIRMAN is whispering to her.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh, I’m glad I’ve got power!

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Power!—you?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Yes, all that money—

div.stage: (LADY JOHN tries to make her way to STONOR.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.stage: (suddenly turning from the CHAIRMAN to the crowd).
sp.p: Oh, yes, I hope you’ll all join the Union. Come up after the meeting and give your names.

sp.speaker: LOUD VOICE.
sp.p: You won’t get many men.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
Then it’s to the women I appeal! (She is about to retire when, with a sudden gleam in her lit eyes, she turns for the last time to the crowd, silencing the general murmur and holding the people by the sudden concentration of passion in her face.) I don’t mean to say it wouldn’t be better if men and women did this work together—shoulder to shoulder.
But the mass of men won’t have it so. I only hope they’ll realise in time the good they’ve renounced and the spirit they’ve aroused. For I know as well as any man could tell me, it would be a bad day for England if all women felt about all men as I do.

div.stage: (She retires in a tumult. The others on the platform close about her. The CHAIRMAN tries in vain to get a hearing from the excited crowd.)
(JEAN tries to make her way through the knot of people surging around her.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Here!—Follow me!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: No—no—I—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You’re going the wrong way.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: This is the way I must go.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You can get out quicker on this side.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: I don’t want to get out.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: What! Where are you going?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: To ask that woman to let me have the honour of working with her.

div.stage: (She disappears in the crowd.)
CURTAIN.

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: SCENE: The drawing‐room at old MR. DUNBARTON’S house in Eaton Square. Six o’clock the same evening. As the Curtain rises the door (L.) opens and JEAN appears on the threshold. She looks back into her own sitting‐room, then crosses the drawing‐room, treading softly on the parquet spaces between the rugs. She goes to the window and is in the act of parting the lace curtains when the folding doors (C.) are opened by the BUTLER.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Sh! (She goes softly back to the door she has left open and closes it carefully. When she turns, the BUTLER has stepped aside to admit GEOFFREY STONOR, and departed, shutting the folding doors. STONOR comes rapidly forward.) (Before he gets a word out.) Speak low please.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p:
I waited about a whole hour for you to come back. (JEAN turns away as though vaguely looking for the nearest chair.)
If you didn’t mind leaving me like that, you might have considered Lady John.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Is she here with you?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: No. My place was nearer than this, and she was very tired. I left her to get some tea. We couldn’t tell whether you’d be here, or what had become of you.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Mr. Trent got us a hansom.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Trent?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: The Chairman of the meeting.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: “Got us—”?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Miss Levering and me.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: MISS L—

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mr. Farnborough.

div.stage: (Enter MR. RICHARD FARNBOROUGH—more flurried than ever.)

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: At last! You’ll forgive this incursion, Miss Dunbarton, when you hear— (Turns abruptly back to STONOR.) They’ve been telegraphing you all over London. In despair they set me on your track.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Who did? What’s up?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.stage: (lays down his hat and fumbles agitatedly in his breast‐pocket).
sp.p: There was the devil to pay at Dutfield last night. The Liberal chap tore down from London and took over your meeting!

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Oh?—Nothing about it in the Sunday paper I saw.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Wait till you see the Press to‐morrow morning! There was a great rally and the beggar made a rousing speech.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: What about?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Abolition of the Upper House—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: They were at that when I was at Eton!

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Yes. But this new man has got a way of putting things!—the people went mad. (Pompously.) The Liberal platform as defined at Dutfield is going to make a big difference.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You think so.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Well, your agent says as much. (Opens telegram.)

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: My— (Taking telegram.) “Try find Stonor”—Hm! Hm!

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: —“tremendous effect of last night’s Liberal manifesto ought to be counteracted in tomorrow’s papers.” (Very earnestly.) You see, Mr. Stonor, it’us a battle‐cry we want.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Claptrap!

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Well, they’ve been saying we have nothing to offer but personal popularity. No practical reform. No—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: No truckling to the masses, I suppose. (Walks impatiently away.)

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Well, in these democratic days—(Turns to JEAN for countenance.) I hope you’ll forgive my bursting in like this. (Struck by her face.) But I can see you realise the gravity— (Lowering his voice with an air of speaking for her ear alone.) It isn’t as if he were going to be a mere private member. Everybody knows he’ll be in the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: It may be a Liberal Cabinet.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Nobody thought so up to last night. Why, even your brother—but I am afraid I’m seeming officious. (Takes up his hat.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: What about my brother?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: I met Lord Windlesham as I rushed out of the Carlton.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Did he say anything?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: I told him the Dutfield news.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: He said it only confirmed his fears.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Said that, did he?

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Yes. Defeat is inevitable, he thinks, unless— (Pause.) (GEOFFREY STONOR, who has been pacing the floor, stops but doesn’t raise his eyes.) unless you can “manufacture some political dynamite within the next few hours.” Those were his words.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (resumes his walking to and fro, raises his head and catches sight of JEAN’S white, drawn face. Stops short).
sp.p: You are very tired.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: No. No.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I’m obliged to you for taking so much trouble. (Shakes hands by way of dismissing FARNBOROUGH.) I’ll see what can be done.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: If you’d like to wire I’ll take it.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You don’t understand, my young friend. Moves of this kind are not rushed at by responsible politicians. I must have time for consideration.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Oh, well, I only hope someone else won’t jump into the breach before you— (Watch in hand) I tell you. (To JEAN.) I’ll find out what time the newspapers go to press on Sunday. Goodbye. (To STONOR.) I’ll be at the Club just in case I can be of any use.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: No, don’t do that. If I should have anything new to say—

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: B‐b‐but with our party, as your brother said—“heading straight for a vast electoral disaster—”

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: If I decide on a counterblast I shall simply telegraph to headquarters. Goodbye.

sp.speaker: FARN.
sp.p: Oh—a—g‐goodbye. (A gesture of “The country’s going to the dogs.”)

div.stage: (JEAN rings the bell. Exit FARNBOROUGH.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: “Political dynamite,” eh? (Pause.) After all . . . women are much more conservative than men—aren’t they? (JEAN looks straight in front of her, making no attempt to reply.) Especially the women the property qualification would bring in. (He glances at JEAN as though for the first time conscious of her silence.) You see now (he throws himself into the chair by the table) one reason why I’ve encouraged you to take an interest in public affairs. Because people like us don’t go screaming about it, is no sign we don’t (some of us) see what’s on the way. However little they want to, women of our class will have to come into line. All the best things in the world—everything that civilisation has won will be in danger if—when this change comes—the only women who have practical political training are the women of the lower classes. Women of the lower classes, and (his brows knit heavily) —women inoculated by the Socialist virus.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p:
Let
us see, how we shall put it—when the time comes—shall we? (He detaches a pencil from his watch chain and bends over the paper, writing.)

div.stage: (JEAN opens her lips to speak, moves a shade nearer the table and then falls back upon her silent, half‐incredulous misery.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Enough dynamite in that! Rather too much, isn’t there, little girl?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Geoffrey, I know her story.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Whose story?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Miss Levering’s.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Vida Levering’s. (STONOR stares speechless. Slight pause.) (The words escaping from her in a miserable cry) Why did you desert her?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I? I?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Oh, why did you do it?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: What in the name of— What has she been saying to you?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Some one else told me part. Then the way you looked when you saw her at Aunt Ellen’s—Miss Levering’s saying you didn’t know her—then your letting out that you knew even the curious name on the handkerchief— Oh, I pieced it together—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Your ingenuity is undeniable!

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: —and then, when she said that at the meeting about “the dark hour” and I looked at your face—it flashed over me— Oh, why did you desert her?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I didn’t desert her.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Ah‐h! (Puts her hands before her eyes.) (STONOR makes a passionate motion towards her, is checked by her muffled voice saying) I’m glad—I’m glad! (He stares bewildered. JEAN drops her hands in her lap and steadies her voice.) She went away from you, then?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You don’t expect me to enter into—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: She went away from you?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (with a look of almost uncontrollable anger).
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Was that because you wouldn’t marry her?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I couldn’t marry her—and she knew it.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Did you want to?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (an instant’s angry scrutiny and then turning away his eyes).
sp.p: I thought I did—then. It’s a long time ago.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: And why “couldn’t” you?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (a movement of strong irritation cut short).
sp.p: Why are you catechising me? It’s a matter that concerns another woman.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: If you’re saying that it doesn’t concern me, you’re saying— (her lip trembles) —that you don’t concern me.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: In those days I—I was absolutely dependent on my father.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Why, you must have been thirty, Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: What? Oh—thereabouts.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: And everybody says you’re so clever.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Well, everybody’s mistaken.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: It must have been terribly hard— (STONOR turns toward her.) for you both— (He arrests his movement and stands stonily.) that a man like you shouldn’t have had the freedom that even the lowest seem to have.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Freedom?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: To marry the woman they choose.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: She didn’t break off our relations because I couldn’t marry her.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Why was it, then?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You’re too young to discuss such a story. (Half turns away.)

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: I’m not so young as she was when—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Very well, then, if you will have it! The truth is, it didn’t seem to weigh upon her, as it seems to on you, that I wasn’t able to marry her.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Why are you so sure of that?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Because she didn’t so much as hint such a thing when she wrote that she meant to break off the—the—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: What made her write like that?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Why will you go on talking of what’s so long over and ended?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: What reason did she give?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: If your curiosity has so got the upper hand—ask her.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You’re afraid to tell me.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (putting pressure on himself to answer quietly).
sp.p:
I still hoped—at that time—to win my father over. She blamed me because (goes to window
and looks blindly out and speaks in a low tone) if the child had lived it wouldn’t have been possible to get my father to—to overlook it.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You wanted it overlooked? I don’t underst—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Of course you don’t. (He seizes her hand and tries to draw her to him.) If you did, you wouldn’t be the beautiful, tender, innocent child you are—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (has withdrawn her hand and shrunk from him with an impulse—slight as is its expression—so tragically eloquent, that fear for the first time catches hold of him).
sp.p: I am glad you didn’t mean to desert her, Geoffrey. It wasn’t your fault after all—only some misunderstanding that can be cleared up.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Yes. Cleared up.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You aren’t thinking that this miserable old affair I’d as good as forgotten—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (in a horror‐struck whisper, with a glance at the door which he doesn’t see).

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: No, no. I don’t mean exactly forgotten. But you’re torturing me so I don’t know what I’m saying. (He goes closer.) You aren’t—Jean! you—you aren’t going to let it come between you and me!

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (presses her handkerchief to her lips, and then, taking it away, answers steadily).
sp.p: I can’t make or unmake what’s past. But I’m glad, at least, that you didn’t mean to desert her in her trouble. You’ll remind her of that first of all, won’t you? (Moves to the door, L.)

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Where are you going? (Raising his voice.) Why should I remind anybody of what I want only to forget?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Sh!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You don’t mean that she’s—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Yes. I left her to get a little rest. (He recoils in an access of uncontrollable rage. She follows him. Speechless, he goes down R. to get his hat.) Geoffrey, don’t go before you hear me. I don’t know if what I think matters to you now—but I hope it does. (With tears.) You can still make me think of you without shrinking—if you will.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (fixes her a moment with his eyes. Then sternly).
sp.p: What is it you are asking of me?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: To make amends, Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You poor little innocent!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: I’m poor enough. But (locking her hands together) I’m not so innocent but what I know you must right that old wrong now, if you’re ever to right it.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You aren’t insane enough to think I would turn round in these few hours and go back to something that ten years ago was ended for ever! Why, it’s stark, staring madness!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: No. (Catching on his arm.) What you did ten years ago—that was mad. This is paying a debt.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Look here, Jean, you’re dreadfully wrought up and excited—tired too—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p:
No, not tired—though I’ve travelled so far to‐day. I know you smile at sudden conversions. You think they’re hysterical—worse—vulgar. But people must get their revelations how they can. And, Geoffrey, if I can’t make you see this one of mine—I
shall know your love could never mean strength to me. Only weakness. And I shall be afraid. So afraid I’ll never dare to give you the chance of making me loathe myself. I shall never see you again.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: How right I was to be afraid of that vein of fanaticism in you. (Moves towards the door.)

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Certainly you couldn’t make a greater mistake than to go away now and think it any good ever to come back. (He turns.) Even if I came to feel different, I couldn’t do anything different. I should know all this couldn’t be forgotten. I should know that it would poison my life in the end. Yours too.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: She has made good use of her time! (With a sudden thought.) What has changed her? Has she been seeing visions too?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Why is she intriguing to get hold of a man that, ten years ago, she flatly refused to see, or hold any communication with?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: “Intriguing to get hold of?” She hasn’t mentioned you!

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: What! Then how in the name of Heaven do you know—that she wants—what you ask?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: There can’t be any doubt about that.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: You absurd, ridiculous child! Then all this is just your own unaided invention. Well—I could thank God! (Falls into the nearest chair and passes his handkerchief over his face.)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: For what are you thanking God?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (trying to think out his plan of action).
sp.p: Suppose—(I’m not going to risk it)—but suppose— (He looks up and at the sight of JEAN’S face a new tenderness comes into his own. He rises suddenly.) Whether I deserve to suffer or not—it’s quite certain you don’t Don’t cry, dear one. It never was the real thing. I had to wait till I knew you before I understood.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh, it that true? (Checks her movement towards him.) Loving you has made things clear to me I didn’t dream of before. If I could think that because of me you were able to do this—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (seizes her by the shoulders and says hoarsely).
sp.p: Look here! Do you seriously ask me to give up the girl I love—to go and offer to marry a woman that even to think of—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: You cared for her once. You’ll care about her again. She is beautiful and brilliant—everything. I’ve heard she could win any man she set herself to—

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: She’s bewitched you!

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Geoffrey, Geoffrey, you aren’t going away like lik that. This isn’t the end!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I suppose even if she refused me, you’d—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: She won’t refuse you.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: She did once.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: She didn’t refuse to marry you—

div.stage: (JEAN is going to the door.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p:
Wait!—a— (Hunting for some means of gaining time.) Lady John
is waiting all this while for the car to go back with a message.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: That’s not a matter of life and death—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: All the same—I’ll go down and give the order.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Very well. (Sits C.) You’ll come back if you’re the man I pray you are. (Breaks into a flood of silent tears, her elbows on the table (C.) her face in her hands.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (returns, bends over her, about to take her in his arms).
sp.p: Dearest of all the world—

div.stage: (Door L. opens softly and VIDA LEVERING appears. She is arrested at the sight of STONOR, and is in the act of drawing back when, upon the slight noise, STONOR looks round. His face darkens, he stands staring at her and then with a look of speechless anger goes silently out C. JEAN, hearing him shut the door, drops her head on the table with a sob. VIDA LEVERING crosses slowly to her and stands a moment silent at the girl’s side.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.stage: (lifting her head and drying her eyes).
sp.p: I—I’ve been seeing Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Is this the effect seeing Geoffrey has?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: You see, I know now (as MISS LEVERING looks quite uncomprehending) —how he (drops her eyes) —how he spoiled some one else’s life.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Who tells you that?

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Several people have told me.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Well, you should be very careful how you believe what you hear.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: You know it’s true.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I know that it’s possible to be mistaken.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: I see! You’re trying to shield him—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Why should I—what is it to me?

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Oh—h, how you must love him!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Listen to me—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: What’s the use of your going on denying it? MISS LEVERING, about to break it, is silenced.) Geoffrey doesn’t (JEAN, struggling to command her feelings, goes to window. VIDA LEVERING relinquishes an impulse to follow, and sits left centre. JEAN comes slowly back with her eyes bent on the floor, does not lift them till she is quite near VIDA. Then the girl’s self‐absorbed face changes.) Oh, don’t look like that! I shall bring him back to you! (Drops on her knees beside the other’s chair.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You would be impertinent (softening) if you weren’t a romantic child. You can’t bring him back.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Yes, he—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: But there’s something you can do—

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Bring him to the point where he recognises that he’s in our debt.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: In our debt?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: In debt to women. He can’t repay the one he robbed—

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No, he can’t repay the dead. But there are the living. There are the thousands with hope still in their hearts and youth in their blood. Let him help them. Let him be a Friend to Women.

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Yes, yes—I understand. That too!

div.stage: (The door opens. As STONOR enters with LADY JOHN, he makes a slight gesture towards the two as much as to say, “You see.”)

sp.speaker: JEAN
sp.p: Thank you!

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.stage: (in a clear, commonplace tone to JEAN).
sp.p: Well, you rather gave us the slip. Vida, I believe Mr. Stonor wants to see you for a few minutes (glances at watch)—but I’d like a word with you first, as I must get back. (To STONOR.) Do you think the car—your man said something about re‐charging.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Oh, did he?—I’ll see about it.

div.stage: (As STONOR is going out he encounters the BUTLER. Exit STONOR.)

sp.speaker: BUTLER.
sp.p: Mr. Trent has called, Miss, to take Miss Levering to the meeting.

sp.speaker: JEAN.
sp.p: Bring Mr. Trent into my sitting‐room. I’ll tell him—you can’t go to‐night.

div.stage: [Exeunt BUTLER C., JEAN L.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I know, my dear, you’re not aware of what that impulsive girl wants to insist on.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Yes, I am aware of it.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: But it isn’t with your sanction, surely, that she goes on making this extraordinary demand.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I didn’t sanction it at first, but I’ve been thinking it over.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Then all I can say is I am greatly disappointed in you. You threw this man over years ago for reasons—whatever they were—that seemed to you good and sufficient. And now you come between him and a younger woman—just to play Nemesis, so far as I can make out!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Is that what he says?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: He says nothing that isn’t fair and considerate.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I can see he’s changed.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: And you’re unchanged—is that it?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I’ve changed more than he.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: But (pity and annoyance blended in her tone)—you care about him still, Vida?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: I see. It’s just that you wish to marry somebody—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh, Lady John, there are no men listening.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: No, I didn’t suppose there were.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Then why keep up that old pretence?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: What pre—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: That to marry at all costs is every woman’s dearest ambition till the grave closes over her. You and I know it isn’t true.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Well, but— Oh! it was just the unexpected sight of him bringing it back— That was what fired you this afternoon! (With an honest attempt at sympathetic understanding.) Of course. The memory of a thing like that can never die—can never even be dimmed—for the woman.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I mean her to think so.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Jean!

div.stage: (MISS LEVERING nods.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: And it isn’t so?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You don’t seriously believe a woman with anything else to think about, comes to the end of ten years still absorbed in a memory of that sort?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You’ve got over it, then!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: If the newspapers didn’t remind me I shouldn’t remember once a twelvemonth that there was ever such a person as Geoffrey Stonor in the world.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh, I’m so glad!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Yes, I’m glad too.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: And if Geoffrey Stonor offered you—what’s called “reparation”—you’d refuse it?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Geoffrey Stonor! For me he’s simply one of the far‐back links in a chain of evidence. It’s certain I think a hundred times of other women’s present unhappiness, to once that I remember that old unhappiness of mine that’s past. I think of the nail and chain makers of Cradley Heath. The sweated girls of the slums. I think of the army of ill‐used women whose very existence I mustn’t mention—

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Then why in Heaven’s name do you let poor Jean imagine—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Look—I’ll trust you, Lady John. I don’t suffer from that old wrong as Jean thinks I do, but I shall coin her sympathy into gold for a greater cause than mine.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: I don’t understand you.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Jean isn’t old enough to be able to care as much about a principle as about a person. But if my half‐forgotten pain can turn her generosity into the common treasury—

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: What do you propose she shall do, poor child?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Use her hold over Geoffrey Stonor to make him help us!

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Help you?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: The man who served one woman—God knows how many more—very ill, shall serve hundreds of thousands well. Geoffrey Stonor shall make it harder for his son, harder still for his grandson, to treat any woman as he treated me.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: How will he do that?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: By putting an end to the helplessness of women.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You must think he has a great deal of power—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Power? Yes, men have too much over penniless and frightened women.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: What nonsense! You talk as though the women hadn’t their share of human nature. We aren’t made of ice any more than the men.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No, but all the same we have more self‐control.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Than men?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You know we have.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I know we mustn’t admit it.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: For fear they’d call us fishes!

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p:
They talk of our lack of
self‐control—but it’s the last thing they want women to have.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh, we know what they want us to have. So we make shift to have it. If we don’t, we go without hope—sometimes we go without bread.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Vida—do you mean to say that you—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I mean to say that men’s vanity won’t let them see it, but the thing’s largely a question of economics.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: You never loved him, then!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I loved him—once. It was my helplessness turned the best thing life can bring, into a curse for both of us.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: I don’t understand you—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh, being “understood!”—that’s too much to expect. When people come to know I’ve joined the Union—

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: But you won’t—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: —who is there who will resist the temptation to say, “Poor Vida Levering! What a pity she hasn’t got a husband and a baby to keep her quiet”? The few who know about me, they’ll be equally sure that it’s not the larger view of life I’ve gained—my own poor little story is responsible for my new departure. (Leans forward and looks into LADY JOHN’S face.) My best friend, she will be surest of all, that it’s a private sense of loss, or, lower yet, a grudge—! But I tell you the only difference between me and thousands of women with husbands and babies is that I’m free to say what I think. They aren’t.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: I must get back—my poor ill‐used guests.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I won’t ring. I think you’ll find Mr. Stonor downstairs waiting for you.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh—a—he will have left word about the car in any case.

div.stage: (MISS LEVERING has opened the door (C.). ALLEN TRENT is in the act of saying goodbye to JEAN in the hall.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Trent, I didn’t expect to see you this evening.

sp.speaker: TRENT
sp.p: Why not? Have I ever failed?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Lady John, this is one of our allies. He is good enough to squire me through the rabble from time to time.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Well, I think it’s very handsome of you, after what she said to‐day about men. (Shakes hands.)

sp.speaker: TRENT.
sp.p: I’ve no great opinion of most men myself. I might add—or of most women.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Oh! Well, at any rate I shall go away relieved to think that Miss Levering’s plain speaking hasn’t alienated all masculine regard.

sp.speaker: TRENT.
sp.p: Why should it?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: That’s right, Mr. Trent! Don’t believe all she says in the heat of propaganda.

sp.speaker: TRENT.
sp.p: I do believe all she says. But I’m not cast down.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Not when she says—

sp.speaker: TRENT
sp.p: Was there ever a mysogynist of my sex who ended by deciding to make an exception?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Oh, if that’s what you build on!

sp.speaker: TRENT.
sp.p: Well, why shouldn’t a man‐hater on your side prove equally open to reason?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: That part of the question doesn’t concern me. I’ve come to a place where I realise that the first battles of this new campaign must be fought by women alone. The only effective help men could give—amendment of the law—they refuse. The rest is nothing.

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Don’t be ungrateful, Vida. Here’s Mr. Trent ready to face criticism in publicly championing you.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: It’s an illusion that I as an individual need Mr. Trent. I am quite safe in the crowd. Please don’t wait for me, and don’t come for me again.

sp.speaker: TRENT
sp.p: Of course if you’d rather—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: And that reminds me. I was asked to thank you and to tell you, too, that they—the women of the Union—they won’t need your chairmanship any more—though that, I beg you to believe, has nothing to do with any feeling of mine.

sp.speaker: TRENT
sp.p: Of course, I know there must be other men ready—better known men—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: It isn’t that. It’s simply that they find a man can’t keep a rowdy meeting in order as well as a woman.

div.stage: (He stares.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: You aren’t serious?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Haven’t you noticed that all their worst disturbances come when men are in charge?

sp.speaker: TRENT.
sp.p: Well—a—(laughs a little ruefully as he moves to the door) I hadn’t connected the two ideas. Goodbye.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Goodbye.

div.stage: (JEAN takes him downstairs, right centre.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: That nice boy’s in love with you.

div.stage: (MISS LEVERING simply looks at her.)

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Goodbye. (They shake hands.) I wish you hadn’t been so unkind to that nice boy!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Do you?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, for then I would be more certain of your telling Geoffrey Stonor that intelligent women don’t nurse their wrongs and lie in wait to punish them.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You are not certain?

sp.speaker: LADY JOHN
sp.p: Are you?

div.stage: (VIDA stands with her eyes on the ground, silent, motionless. LADY JOHN, with a nervous glance at her watch and a gesture of extreme perturbation, goes hurriedly out. VIDA shuts the door. She comes slowly back, sits down and covers her face with her hands. She rises and begins to walk up and down, obviously trying to master her agitation. Enter GEOFFREY STONOR.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Well, have they primed you? Have you got your lesson (with a little broken laugh) by heart at last?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p:
I am not sure I understand you. (Pause.) However unpropitious your mood may be—I shall discharge my errand. (Pause. Her silence irritates
him.) I have promised to offer you what I believe is called “amends.”

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You’ve come to realise, then—after all these years—that you owed me something?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (on the brink of protest, checks himself).
sp.p: I am not here to deny it.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Pay, then—pay.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (a moment’s dread as he looks at her, his lips set. Then stonily).
sp.p: I have promised that, if you exact it, I will.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Ah! If I insist you’ll “make it all good”! (Quite low.) Then don’t you know you must pay me in kind?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: What do you mean.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Give me back what you took from me: my old faith. Give me that.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Oh, if you mean to make phrases— (A gesture of scant patience.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Or give me back mere kindness—or even tolerance. Oh, I don’t mean your tolerance! Give me back the power to think fairly of my brothers—not as mockers—thieves.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I have not mocked you. And I have asked you—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Something you knew I should refuse! Or (her eyes blaze) did you dare to be afraid I wouldn’t?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I suppose, if we set our teeth, we could—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I couldn’—not even if I set my teeth. And you wouldn’t dream of asking me, if you thought there was the smallest chance.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p:
I can do no more than make you an offer of such reparation as in my power. If you
don’t accept it— (He turns with an air of “That’s done.”)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Accept it? No! . . . Go away and live in debt! Pay and pay—and find yourself still in debt!—for a thing you’ll never be able to give me back. (Lower.) And when you come to die, say to yourself, “I paid all creditors but one.”

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I’m rather tired, you know, of this talk of debt. If I hear that you persist in it I shall have to—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: What? (she faces him).

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: No. I’ll keep my resolution. (Turning to the door.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: What resolution?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I came here, under considerable pressure, to speak of the future—not to re‐open the past.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: The Future and the Past are one.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You talk as if that old madness was mine alone. It is the woman’s way.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I know. And it’s not fair. Men suffer as well as we by the woman’s starting wrong. We are taught to think the man a sort of demigod. If he tells her: “go down into Hell”—down into Hell she goes.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Make no mistake. Not the woman alone. They go down together.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Yes, they go down together, but the man comes up alone. As a rule. It is more convenient so—for him. And for the Other Woman.

div.stage: (The eyes of both go to JEAN’S door.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: My conscience is clear. I know—and so do you—that most men in my position wouldn’t have troubled themselves. I gave myself endless trouble.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: So you’ve gone about all these years feeling that you’d discharged every obligation.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Not only that. I stood by you with a fidelity that was nothing short of Quixotic. If, woman like, you must recall the Past—I insist on your recalling it correctly.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You think I don’t recall it correctly?

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Not when you make—other people believe that I deserted you. (With gathering wrath.) It’s a curious enough charge when you stop to consider— (Checks himself, and with a gesture of impatience sweeps the whole thing out of his way.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Well, when we do—just for five minutes out of ten years—when we do stop to consider—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: We remember it was you who did the deserting! Since you had to rake the story up, you might have had the fairness to tell the facts.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You think “the facts” would have excused you! (She sits.)

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: No doubt you’ve forgotten them, since Lady John tells me you wouldn’t remember my existence once a year if the newspapers didn’t—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Ah, you minded that!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: I minded your giving false impressions. (She is about to speak, he advances on her.) Do you deny that you returned my letters unopened?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Do you deny that you refused to see me—and that, when I persisted, you vanished?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I don’t deny any of those things.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Why, I had no trace of you for years!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I suppose not.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Very well, then. What could I do?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Nothing. It was too late to do anything.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: It wasn’t too late! You knew—since you “read the papers”—that my father died that same year. There was no longer any barrier between us.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh yes, there was a barrier.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Of your own making, then.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I had my guilty share in it—but the barrier (her voice trembles) —the barrier was your invention.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: It was no “invention.” If you had ever known my father—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Oh, the echoes! How often you used to say, if I “knew your father!” But you said, too (lower)—you called the greatest barrier by another name.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: What name?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: The child that was to come.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: That was before my father died. While I still hoped to get his consent.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: How the thought of that all‐powerful personage used to terrorise me! What chance had a little unborn child against “the last of the great feudal lords,” as you called him.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You know the child would have stood between you and me!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I know the child did stand between you and me!

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: It did stand—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Happy mothers teach their children. Mine had to teach me.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You talk as if—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: —teach me that a woman may do a thing for love’s sake that shall kill love.

div.stage: (A silence.)

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (fearing and putting from him fuller comprehension, rises with an air of finality).
sp.p: You certainly made it plain you had no love left for me.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I had need of it all for the child.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (stares—comes closer, speaks hurriedly and very low).
sp.p: Do you mean then that, after all—it lived?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No; I mean that it was sacrificed. But it showed me no barrier is so impassible as the one a little child can raise.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Was that why you . . . was that why?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Day and night there it was!—between my thought of you and me. (He sits again, staring at her.) When I was most unhappy I would wake, thinking I heard it cry. It was my own crying I heard, but I seemed to have it in my arms. I suppose I was mad. I used to lie there in that lonely farmhouse pretending to hush it. It was so I hushed myself.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I never knew—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I didn’t blame you. You couldn’t risk being with me.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You agreed that for both our sakes—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Yes, you had to be very circumspect. You were so well known. Your autocratic father—your brilliant political future—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Be fair. Our future—as I saw it then.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p:
Yes, it all hung on concealment. It must have looked quite simple to you. You didn’t
know that the ghost of a child that had never seen the light, the frail thing you meant to sweep aside and forget—have swept aside and forgotten—you didn’t know it was strong enough to push you out of my life, (Lower with an added intensity.) It can do more. (Leans over to him and whispers.) It can push that girl out. (STONOR’S face changes.) It can do more still.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: Are you threatening me?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: No, I am preparing you.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: For the work that must be done. Either with your help—or that girl’s.

div.stage: (STONOR lifts his eyes a moment.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: One of two things. Either her life, and all she has, given to this new service—or a Ransom, if I give her up to you.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: I see. A price. Well—?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.stage: (looks searchingly in his face, hesitates and shakes her head).
sp.p: Even if I could trust you to pay—no, it would be a poor bargain to give her up for anything you could do.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: In spite of your assumption—she may not be your tool.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You are horribly afraid she is! But you are wrong. Don’t think it’s merely I that have got hold of Jean Dunbarton.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: Who else?

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: The New Spirit that’s abroad.

div.stage: (STONOR turns away with an exclamation and begins to pace, sentinel‐like, up and down before JEAN’S door.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: How else should that inexperienced girl have felt the new loyalty and responded as she did?

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: “New” indeed—however little loyal.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Loyal above all. But no newer than electricity was when it first lit up the world. It had been there since the world began—waiting to do away with the dark. So has the thing you’re fighting.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.stage: (his voice held down to its lowest register).
sp.p: The thing I’m fighting is nothing more than one person’s hold on a highly sensitive imagination. I consented to this interview with the hope—(A gesture of impotence.) It only remains for me to show her your true motive is revenge.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: Once say that to her and you are lost!

div.stage: (STONOR motionless; his look is the look of a man who sees happiness slipping away.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: I know what it is that men fear. It even seems as if it must be through fear that your enlightenment will come. That is why I see a value in Jean Dunbarton far beyond her fortune.

div.stage: (STONOR lifts his eyes dully and fixes them on VIDA’S face.)

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: More than any girl I know—if I keep her from you—that gentle, inflexible creature could rouse in men the old half‐superstitious fear—

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: “Fear?” I believe you are mad.

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: “Mad.” “Unsexed.” These are the words to‐day. In the Middle Ages men cried out “Witch!” and burnt her—the woman who served no man’s bed or board.

sp.speaker: STONOR.
sp.p: You want to make that poor child believe—

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: She sees for herself we’ve come to a place where we find there’s a value in women apart from the value men see in them. You teach us not to look to you for some of the things we need most. If women must be freed by women, we have need of such as—(her eyes go to JEAN’S door)—who knows? She may be the new Joan of Arc.

sp.speaker: STONOR
sp.p: That she should be the sacrifice!

sp.speaker: MISS L.
sp.p: You have taught us to look very calmly on the sacrifice of women. Men tell us in every tongue it’s “a necessary evil.”
